Article.ArticleTitle: Analysis of Ozone Photochemistry over Southern Tropical Megacity, Bengaluru, India.

AbstractText: Rapid infrastructure development, increased population, shift in land use practices and higher vehicular emissions have all influenced Ozone (O<sub>3</sub> ) production through its precursor gases in southern megacity, Bengaluru, India. We have investigated the photochemistry using hourly measurements of O<sub>3</sub> and associated precursor gases conducted in Bengaluru during January to December 2019. The rate of formation of O<sub>3</sub> is analyzed for Bengaluru for the first time using a photochemical model involving NOx cycle. On the diurnal scale, O<sub>3</sub> showed a midday peak (1200-1500 IST), while its precursors showed a bimodal trend with peaks at 0900 IST and 2100 IST. The photolytic rate constants for <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>j</mi> <msub><mtext>NO</mtext> <mn>2</mn></msub> </msub> </math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>j</mi> <msub><mi>O</mi> <mn>3</mn></msub> </msub> </math> were derived from the tropospheric ultraviolet and visible (TUV) radiation model. Using the photolytic rate constants for <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>j</mi> <msub><mtext>NO</mtext> <mn>2</mn></msub> </msub> </math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>j</mi> <msub><mi>O</mi> <mn>3</mn></msub> </msub> </math> under the triad NO-NO<sub>2</sub> -O<sub>3</sub> , photostationary state (PSS), Leighton ratio (Ф) and its deviations from unity were estimated over Bengaluru. Positive anomalies (Φ > 1) were obtained, and the computed Φ was utilized to determine the total mixing ratios of the peroxy radical (PO<sub>2</sub> ). The seasonal variation in <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>j</mi> <mrow><msub><mtext>O</mtext> <mn>3</mn></msub> </mrow> </msub> </math> revealed that in the presence of intense solar radiation and NOx, VOCs, CO and NMVOCs in the mixing layer, O<sub>3</sub> forms photochemically over the surface.
